ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to reason, dissect the arguments of various thinkers, and come up with compelling counterarguments.

So many amazing philosophers! We were able to read and analyze some really incredible modern philosophy this term and I really loved many of the works that we read. Really liked Berkeley, Descartes, Murdoch, Kierkegaard.
The ability to analyze philosophic texts and write about them effectively.
Written analysis skills, critical speaking skills

I learned how to engage with the ideas of modern philosophers and how to construct an objection on the fly by thinking creatively about the examples presented in an argument and using thought experiments to refute them.
I became a better reader of philosophical texts, and a better author of philosophical essays.
I learned about many different philosophers approaches to epistemological and metaphysical questions and how to write essays that challenge their answers to these questions.
Development of philosophical arguments and counterarguments, and I also improved as a writer in general.
familiarity with influential ideas in philosophy; improved thinking about questions such as 'what is the self?'

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Grimstad did an excellent job laying out the arguments of our thinkers, as well as encouraging us to explain the arguments and give our critiques and objections. The seminar-style format kept us all actively engaged.

Strengths: Really open and free discussion during class of all the philosophers, especially important arguments and points of confusion. Grimstad is a great facilitator of conversation, and there definitely was a lot of it. Weaknesses: People did not get to speak enough. Some voices dominated the conversation. It wasn't very structured either, and the question addressed would often be unclear. It got boring sometimes, with people rehashing the same point over and over. Some questions were left unanswered, which was slightly frustrating.

STRENGTHS: welcoming Professor willing to offer his own time to ensure student success and actualization; strong and comprehensive reading list
WEAKNESSES: size of class was too large for seminar format.
This course manages to cover a lot of challenging material very fast, but I still felt like I got enough support to keep up. The flexibility of class sessions was also really nice in that regard.

Particularly toward the end of the semester, I'd have preferred more curated reading assignments. I appreciate that Directed Studies values reading texts in their original context, but I think for each work, it'd be nice to assign a) required reading for seminar, and b) suggested reading for the essays and final. (And to do (roughly) the same required reading & suggested reading for all sections.) Counterintuitively, in focusing the reading for the seminar, I think it would broaden actual seminar discussions beyond just the first few pages of a text. 

(I think something like Prof. Werner's handouts or Prof. Lindskog's questions for discussion could also help facilitate discussion.)

The discussions were very lively and the lectures were helpful in understanding the texts, but at times it moved too fast for me to keep up, especially during the difficult readings of Kant. The reading load of Kant especially was overwhelming since he is so hard to understand, so it could possibly be improved by either decreasing the amount of readings or increasing the class time around him, although it might just be my personal struggle with understanding him.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I appreciated the accessibility of Zoom office hours.
Too many people in class, this section was quite big. Wish we could have had some time for breakout rooms. Sometimes students who raise their hand in the Zoom window were overlooked.
Extensive offerings of virtual office hours

I think I will miss recorded lectures next year. Not because I won't enjoy being able to watch in-person lectures with my peers and ask questions afterward, but because being able to rewatch recorded lectures before the final is quite nice.

I still think there's room to improve Zoom seminars, but I'm not sure exactly how. Sorry.
Everything worked well

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This course made me decide to pursue philosophy as a major. I always looked forward to getting to discuss the arguments presented by our thinkers in class and challenge those arguments.

I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in receiving a broad overview of western philosophical history. I would not necessarily recommend this class to someone who wants to study philosophy very deeply. However, it does provide a solid background for anyone who is interested in philosophy.

ABSOLUTELY! I really loved engaging with all of the philosophers in section and with my friends. Grimstad was a little... esoteric, I suppose, and he had some difficulty relating to the students, but the readings alone make the class worth it. Not to mention the discussions that would go on outside of the main oneespecially in the chat box. We had so many in-class jokes and interesting debates.
If you are interested in modern philosophy it is a great course but the authors we read second semester are very difficult and detailed.
Yes; Professor Grimstads welcoming attitude encourages high student participation and spirited discussion.
I would recommend this course to students who enjoy reading philosophy and enjoy arguing.

Yes. The works broaden your mind, the seminars and lecture refine your understanding of what you've read, and the essays force you to apply what you've learned. I think it lies at the heart of the liberal arts experience. 

(There's definitely more reasons, but the course evaluation tool was a pretty easy sell.)
I would definitely recommend Paul Grimstads class  he is an excellent professor and I learned so much from him.

I would hesitantly recommend it. I enjoyed DS as a whole, and I also enjoyed most of philosophy and loved reading Descartes and Hume, but the later readings of the semester are extremely difficult and time consuming, so I would not recommend it to most students unless I knew they would be up for it or if they had an interest in philosophy.
yes; reading the philosophical texts deepens your sort of base-line thinking about human questions

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lecture released at the beginning of the week and then two discussion sections.
Virtual office hours via Zoom
recorded lecture

Weekly recorded lecture and two weekly live seminars
